Module kivakit.core
Package com.telenav.kivakit.core.function

Class Result<Value>

java.lang.Object
com.telenav.kivakit.core.function.Maybe<Value>
com.telenav.kivakit.core.function.Result<Value>
All Implemented Interfaces:
SilentTryTrait, Broadcaster, Listener, Repeater, RepeaterMixin, Transceiver, Receiver, Transmitter, Presence, NamedObject, Mixin
public class Result<Value> extends Maybe<Value> implements RepeaterMixin
Represents the result of an operation, capturing any failure messages(). If there are no failure messages, the operation was successful and Maybe.get() provides the value of the operation. Note that a Result is a subclass of Maybe. The list of methods inherited from Maybe are duplicated here for convenience.



Construction

A Result can be constructed in several ways:

  1. absent() - A successful Result with no value
  2. success(Maybe) - Creates a Result with the given value
  3. success(Object) - Creates a Result with the given value
  4. failure(String, Object...) - Creates a Result with the given failure message
  5. failure(Throwable, String, Object...) - Creates a Result with the given failure message



Validation

  • succeeded() - True if this result represents success
  • failed() - True if this result represents a failure
  • isValid() - True if this result is valid. A valid result must have either a value, or one or more messages, but it cannot have both.
  • messages() - Any captured error messages



Terminal Operations

  • Maybe.isPresent() - Returns true if a value is present
  • Maybe.isAbsent() - Returns true if no value is present
  • Maybe.get() - Any value that might be present, or null if no value is present
  • Maybe.has() - Returns true if a value is present
  • orMaybe(Object) - Returns this value, or the default value
  • orMaybe(Source) - Returns this value, or the default value
  • orProblem(String, Object[]) - Returns this value or broadcasts a problem if this value is not present
  • Maybe.orThrow(String, Object...) - Returns this value or throws an exception
  • Maybe.orThrow()- Returns this value or throws an exception
  • Maybe.asStream() - Converts this value to a stream with zero or one element(s)



Functions

  • then(Function) - Returns the result of applying the given function to this value
  • map(BiFunction, Object) - Returns the result of applying the given two-argument function to this value and the given argument
  • map(TriFunction, Object, Object) - Returns the result of applying the given three-argument function to this value and the given arguments
  • map(TetraFunction, Object, Object, Object) - Returns the result of applying the given four-argument function to this value and the given arguments
  • map(PentaFunction, Object, Object, Object, Object) - Returns the result of applying the given five-argument function to this value and the given arguments
  • apply(Function) - Applies the given function to this value
  • map(Function) - Applies the given function to this value



Conditionals

  • presentIf(BooleanFunction) - Applies the given function to this value, returning this value if it is true, or absent() if it is false
  • ifPresent(Consumer) - Calls the given consumer if a value is present
  • ifPresentOr(Consumer, UncheckedVoidCode) - Calls the given consumer if a value is present, otherwise calls the given code
  • or(Code) - If a value is present, returns this value, otherwise returns the Maybe supplied by the given Code



Author:
jonathanl (shibo)
See Also:
Maybe, Consumer, Broadcaster, BiFunction, Function, Code, Source

    • apply

      public <Mapped> Result<Mapped> apply​(Function<? super Value,​? extends Maybe<? extends Mapped>> function)

      Down-casting override

      If a value is present, uses the given function to map the value from Value to Maybe<ResultType>. If no value is present, returns Maybe.absent(). The effect is that of allowing functions to be chained together in a nested structure where each nested function introduces a new lambda variable that is visible to inner functions. For example: 

       var seven = present(7);
 var three = present(3);

 var sum = seven.apply(a ->
               three.apply(b ->
                   present(a + b)))
           .get();

      In this example, if either seven or three had no value present (or both values were absent), the statement would return Maybe.absent(). Only if both values are present will the statement result in the sum of the two values. This allows us to stop thinking about the special case where one or both values are missing.

      Monadic Terminology

      Note that this method is sometimes referred to as flatMap. However, the name 'flatMap' does not accurately describe what this method does, as it only describes what happens when values are collections.

      Important Note

      Notice that the first sentence of the description for this method is exactly the same as that provided for Maybe.map(Function). The difference between the two methods is that the function passed to this method produces Maybe<ResultType> directly (which allows function nesting), while the function passed to Maybe.map(Function) just maps the value to the ResultType type, which is then wrapped in a Maybe.

      Overrides:
      apply in class Maybe<Value>
      Type Parameters:
      Mapped - The type being mapped to
      Parameters:
      function - A function mapping from Value to Maybe<ResultType>
      Returns:
      The mapped value as a Maybe object, or Maybe.absent() if no value was present

    • convert

      public <Output,​ Mapper extends StringMapper<? extends Output>> Maybe<Output> convert​(Class<Mapper> mapperType)
      If a value is present, converts it to a string and then applies the given StringMapper class to convert it to a value. The StringMapper must have a public constructor that takes a Listener. String converters in the kivakit-converter mini-framework are such StringMappers.
      Parameters:
      mapperType - The StringMapper class
      Returns:
      A Maybe object with the mapped value, or absent() if the mapping failed

    • isValid

      public boolean isValid()
      Description copied from class: Maybe
      Returns true if this object is valid
      Overrides:
      isValid in class Maybe<Value>
      Returns:
      True if this result is valid. A result is invalid if it has a value present, but also has failure messages. Note that a result can have neither a value nor any failure messages (see absent()).

    • map

      public <Output> Result<Output> map​(Function<? super Value,​? extends Output> mapper)

      Down-casting override

      If a value is present, uses the given function to map the value from Value to ResultType. The mapped value is then wrapped in a Maybe<ResultType> object and returned. If no value is present, returns Maybe.absent(). The effect is that of simply mapping this optional value to a new type.

      Important Note

      Notice that the first sentence of the description for this method is exactly the same as that provided for Maybe.apply(Function). The difference between the two methods is that the function passed to Maybe.apply(Function) produces Maybe<ResultType> directly (which allows function nesting), while the function passed to this method just maps the value to the ResultType type, which is then wrapped in a Maybe.

      Overrides:
      map in class Maybe<Value>
      Type Parameters:
      Output - The type that Value is being mapped to
      Parameters:
      mapper - A function mapping from Value to ResultType
      Returns:
      The mapped value or Maybe.absent()

    • map

      public <Argument2,​ R> Result<R> map​(BiFunction<Value,​Argument2,​R> function, Argument2 argument2)

      Down-casting override

      If a value is present and the given value is not null, applies the given bi-function to produce a result of a different type.

      Overrides:
      map in class Maybe<Value>
      Parameters:
      function - The bi-function, f(Value, Argument2) -> ResultType
      argument2 - The second argument to pass to the bi-function, along with this value as the first argument
      Returns:
      The combination of this value and the given argument, if both values are non-null, otherwise, returns Maybe.absent().

    • map

      public <Argument2,​ Argument3,​ ResultType> Result<ResultType> map​(TriFunction<Value,​Argument2,​Argument3,​ResultType> function, Argument2 argument2, Argument3 argument3)

      Down-casting override

      If a value is present, and the given arguments are non-null, applies the given tri-function to produce a result of a different type.

      Overrides:
      map in class Maybe<Value>
      Parameters:
      function - The tri-function, f(Value, Argument2, Argument3) -> ResultType
      argument2 - The second argument to pass to the tri-function, along with this value as the first argument
      argument3 - The third argument to pass to the tri-function
      Returns:
      The combination of this value and the given arguments, if all arguments are non-null, otherwise, returns Maybe.absent().

    • map

      Down-casting override

      argument4 - The fourth argument to pass to the quad-function along with this value
      Returns:

    • or

      public Result<Value> or​(Code<Value> code)
      If this result failed, runs the given Code, capturing any messages and result of the call. If the code succeeds, returns the result, otherwise returns this result.
      Returns:
      The Result of the call

    • presentIf

      public Result<Value> presentIf​(BooleanFunction<Value> predicate)

      Down-casting override

      If this value is not null and the given predicate evaluates to true for the value, returns this value, otherwise returns the Maybe.absent() value.

      Overrides:
      presentIf in class Maybe<Value>
      Parameters:
      predicate - The predicate to test any non-null value
      Returns:
